body: Should use function call getTestRootPath() instead of `pwd`
In this pull request, I also fix comment bug for https://github.com/apache/incubator-hawq/pull/665 together.
Bundled fixing in https://github.com/apache/incubator-hawq/pull/674, and already merged into master.

The main hawq register steps are as follows:
get_files_in_hdfs(filepath)
check_parquet_format(options, files)
firstsegno = get_metadata_from_database(options, databasename, seg_name)
move_files_in_hdfs(options, databasename, tablename, files, firstsegno, True)
insert_metadata_into_database(options, databasename, tablename, seg_name, firstsegno, sizes)

I have a question what will happen when one of some steps fails. E.g. hdfs files have been moved, but insert metadata failed, should we restore the moved data?

Create HAWQ JIRA issue for this PR: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HAWQ-763

@vraghavan78 please change this PR title and commit message starting with `HAWQ-763. Remove traceflag that allows ORCA to run in multiple threads`, which follows the apache HAWQ PR requirement.

HAWQ JIRA issue was created for this PR: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HAWQ-764
@vraghavan78 Please update this PR.

Apache HAWQ JIRA issue was created for this PR:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HAWQ-765

> The main hawq register steps are as follows:
> get_files_in_hdfs(filepath)
> check_parquet_format(options, files)
> firstsegno = get_metadata_from_database(options, databasename, seg_name)
> move_files_in_hdfs(options, databasename, tablename, files, firstsegno, True)
> insert_metadata_into_database(options, databasename, tablename, seg_name, firstsegno, sizes)

If one of the reads fails, we just exit cause no file has been changed. If move_files_in_hdfs fails, the metadata will not be inserted. If insert_metadata_into_database fails, we will move the files back to their original location.
cc @zhangh43 plz review the first commit, @wengyanqing @ztao1987 plz review the second commit, @ictmalili plz review the third commit.

@wengyanqing I try to run `feature-test` together with `valgrind` but got some lost and leak. I am not sure  what's the problem(maybe gtest, mac, valgrind itself), have you ever tried that in running `feature-test`?

How do you expect users to execute this in their SQL script?
Suppose the work flow is 
CREATE TABEL ....
DO SOME QUERY ...
DO MORE ANALYSIS ...

In this case, user just needs to run one .sql file. Now they need to break the flow in between and switch out to shell to _register_?
-1

@GodenYao, good point. from sql side, it is just like loading data into native tables. the pure sql flow is like this: 

1) create table
2) create external web table that executes the "hawq register" command and load the data
3) more queries

Thanks @changleicn , my questions:
1) where is the logic for external web tables to invoke this cmd tool in the code change? 
2) create external tables has special semantic meaning in this case, I don't see a good way to combine this logic with existing external table DDL

Please see the doc here: http://hdb.docs.pivotal.io/200/hawq/reference/sql/CREATE-EXTERNAL-TABLE.html

we also use external tables to execute "dbgen" command to load tpch data. this is somewhat common from customer side when loading data.

I'm aware of grammar of external web table from GPDB.
Here's an example:

```
=# CREATE EXTERNAL WEB TABLE output (output text)
    EXECUTE 'PATH=/home/gpadmin/programs; export PATH; myprogram.sh' 
    FORMAT 'TEXT';
```

However, your implementation requires creating a native table first - which is not falling into create external web table DDL at all.

Then user needs to run cmdline tool to **register** a new path of the file which would swap the original paq file created by the original DDL.

Furthermore, I think you mixed the usage of this EXTERNAL WEB TABLE, which is more for output and expect a stream of row records:

> Similar to readable web external tables that execute a command or program, writable external web tables can also be defined to send output rows to an executable program or script. The executable program used in the writable external table definition must be prepared to accept an input stream, reside in the same location on all of the Greenplum segment hosts, and be executable by the gpadmin user. The command specified in your writable external table definition is executed by all segments in the Greenplum system, whether or not a segment has output rows to process or not.

While your command "hawq register ..." does nothing about streaming row records but change the native table's file path, so it's not comparable to this DDL's usage.

Had a offline discussion with @GodenYao. This command line is used to register existing hdfs files to hawq native tables and it is used in use cases such as ingesting data from spark, storm et al. And we should not mix this with other external table usage.
@shivzone "mv" is almost zero cost in hdfs. Copy in hawq is serial and slow, does not work here,

I was thinking of move file from any location eg: (S3/localFS,etc).
If the source is strictly hdfs, move being a metadata only operation is definitely more efficient.
My suggestion was to use a command like LOAD/MOVE FROM so that we stick to the SQL style syntax.

`src/test/feature/query/test-insert.cpp` -> `src/test/feature/query/test_insert.cpp`, I think we should be the same filename-style with Postgresql which uses underscores, but for makefile targets, we could use dashes. I have already modified the past code, so don't worry.
Close this pull request. Move the code review to https://github.com/apache/incubator-hawq/pull/686 due to manual merge of latest test framework refactor.

@shivzone Indeed if we further need to register file from other location, simple "mv" doesn't work. But I think in hdfs it works currently now. 

Btw,@shivzone, @changleicn  can we move the discussion to JIRA  https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HAWQ-760?

What's the issue for registering files from another HDFS cluster?
If the node that's running the tool can access the other cluster, wouldn't it succeed? (as your register will pull the file into hawq data directory)?

@GodenYao Currently the implementation is by calling "dfs mv" command, this command doesn't support moving data file between clusters.  If there's need for moving from another cluster, we can modify this policy.

I tested the changes on RHEL6.5, seems many commands in the script are not available. 

And as my check, no others using this script, beside the function of this script is not important. It just do a simple test of disk speed. 

So I suggest we remove this file.

[gpadmin@test1 bin]$ ./diskqual.ksh
./diskqual.ksh: line 2: format: command not found
./diskqual.ksh: line 2: nawk: command not found
